Article Title: Creating and sharing these photos will soon be a crime in UK
Article Text:
What the proposed laws say and punishment

The UK government has announced that it will criminalise the creation and sharing of sexually explicit deepfake images . The government will also introduce a new rule under which perpetrators will be charged for both creating and sharing these images. The move aims to strengthen protections for women and girls against image-based abuse.“Predators who create sexually explicit ‘deepfakes’ could face prosecution as the Government bears down on vile online abuse as part of its mission to make our streets safer,” the government said, adding, “The proliferation of these hyper-realistic images has grown at an alarming rate, causing devastating harm to victims, particularly women and girls who are often the target.”The proposed legislation will make it a criminal offense to create deepfakes without consent, punishable by up to two years in prison. This move closes a gap in existing laws, which currently only criminalise the sharing or threat of sharing intimate images, including deepfakes.The UK government will also create new offences for the taking of intimate images without consent and the installation of equipment with intent to commit these offences.Victims Minister Alex Davies-Jones emphasised the urgency of addressing this issue, citing that one in three women in the UK have been victims of online abuse.“This demeaning and disgusting form of chauvinism must not become normalised, and as part of our Plan for Change we are bearing down on violence against women – whatever form it takes. These new offences will help prevent people being victimised online. We are putting offenders on notice – they will face the full force of the law,” said Davies-Jones.These new offences follow the UK government’s action in September 2024 to add sharing intimate image offences as priority offences under the Online Safety Act.
Article Summary: The UK government has announced that it will criminalise the creation and sharing of sexually explicit deepfake images. The move aims to strengthen protections for women and girls against image-based abuse. The proposed legislation will make it a criminal offense to create deepfakes without consent, punishable by two years in prison.

Article Title: Elon Musk responds to Facebook ‘dumping’ fact checkers, for X-like feature: This is …
Article Text: Meta is ending its third-party fact-checking program in the United States, replacing it with a community-driven system similar to Elon Musk's X platform, drawing immediate praise from the tech billionaire."This is cool," Musk posted on X in response to Meta's announcement of the major content moderation shift.The change marks a significant departure from Meta's seven-year-old fact-checking system, which relied on approximately 80 independent organizations globally to verify content on Facebook and Instagram. Instead, Meta will adopt a model where users can add contextual notes to potentially misleading posts, mirroring the approach used on X.Joel Kaplan, Meta's chief global affairs officer, acknowledged that the company's content moderation had "gone too far," resulting in excessive censorship and mistaken content removals. In December 2024 alone, Meta estimates 10-20% of content takedowns may have been errors.The move comes as Meta appears to be aligning itself with the incoming Trump administration, having recently appointed longtime Republican Kaplan to head global policy and added Trump ally Dana White to its board of directors. Trump's FCC nominee Brendan Carr celebrated the announcement, suggesting support for reduced content moderation.The changes will be gradually implemented in the US over several months. Users can now sign up to become contributors to the Community Notes program on Facebook, Instagram, and Threads. Meta emphasized that the new system will require agreement between users with diverse perspectives to prevent biased ratings.The company clarified that these changes will not be implemented in the European Union for now, as it reviews its content moderation obligations in that region.
Article Summary: Meta is ending its third-party fact-checking program in the United States. The company will replace it with a community-driven system similar to Elon Musk's X platform. The changes will be gradually implemented in the US over several months. Meta estimates 10-20% of content takedowns may have been errors.

Article Title: Airbnb blocked 74,000 bookings worldwide on New Year eve in 2023, and says will follow same measures in 2024 as well
Article Text:
How Airbnb checks ‘party’ booking

Planning a New Year's Eve party at an Airbnb? Think again. The company is deploying anti-party technology globally to prevent "unauthorized and disruptive" gatherings during the holiday season. This technology uses machine learning to identify and block risky bookings, focusing on factors like trip length, booking timing, and distance from the guest's location. While implemented worldwide, the technology will specifically target the US, UK, Australia, Canada, France, Puerto Rico, Spain and New Zealand. Last New Year's Eve, Airbnb blocked 74,000 such bookings.High-risk bookings will be blocked or redirected to alternative accommodations. Short holiday getaways (one to three nights) in entire homes will also be restricted, and guests booking entire homes will be required to agree to a "mandatory anti-party attestation." "If a booking is identified as higher risk, the guest will either be blocked from booking, or redirected to alternative accommodations on the platform," the company said.Guests will also be required to accept mandatory anti-party attestation. "Guests who can make reservations will need to confirm that they understand that disruptive and unauthorized parties are not allowed on Airbnb, and they face suspension or removal from the platform if they violate this policy," said the company.Airbnb also has a 'Neighborhood Support Line' for local communities to report urgent issues, like a party in progress, at a home they believe is listed on Airbnb.Airbnb's efforts to curb disruptive parties started in 2019 with a ban on "party houses," followed by stricter measures in 2020 due to the pandemic. In 2022, the company permanently banned large parties worldwide following several violent incidents at Airbnb rentals, including a shooting in Pittsburgh that resulted in two deaths and eight injuries.
Article Summary: Airbnb is deploying anti-party technology globally to prevent "unauthorized and disruptive" gatherings during the holiday season. The technology uses machine learning to identify and block risky bookings, focusing on factors like trip length, booking timing, and distance from the guest's location.

It works the best with liquids like soups and sauces, and the food needs to have some salt for the effect to work. And, you need to wash the spoon by hand.

Article Title: CES 2025: Nvidia unveils AI models to train robots and autonomous vehicles

This means that researchers and developers, regardless of their company size, can freely use these models under NVIDIA's permissive open-source license, even for commercial purposes.This open approach aims to democratise access to AI technology and accelerate the development of next-generation robots and AVs.Additionally, Nvidia envisions Cosmos, combined with its Omniverse platform, as a “multiverse simulation engine”, allowing AI agents to simulate virtually infinite scenarios and choose the best course of action, leading to more efficient and robust robot behaviour.Cosmos also includes an accelerated data processing pipeline, enabling developers to process massive amounts of data significantly faster than traditional methods.

Artificial intelligence (AI) took center stage in 2024, with its rapid evolution sparking debates about its potential to reshape industries and daily life. As we step into 2025, leading voices in the tech industry are predicting the next wave of AI innovations. These forecasts encompass its impact on workplaces, consumer behavior, and societal values. While AI promises increased efficiency and transformation, concerns surrounding job displacement, ethical considerations, and resistance are growing. Here are predictions and insights from prominent tech leaders, offering a comprehensive view of AI’s trajectory in 2025.Sam Altman, CEO of OpenAI, envisions 2025 as the year when AI agents become an integral part of the workforce. He emphasizes the role of agentic AI, which relies on generative AI (GenAI) to function as "digital coworkers."Altman predicts these AI agents will materially enhance productivity across industries by automating repetitive tasks and augmenting human capabilities. In a recent blog post, he stated, “We continue to believe that iteratively putting great tools in the hands of people leads to great, broadly-distributed outcomes.”However, Altman acknowledges the growing concerns about job security as AI becomes mainstream. Businesses adopting this technology must balance innovation with strategies to ensure workforce sustainability and skill development.Bill Gates has long advocated for the importance of education in adapting to technological advancements. He has repeatedly stated that by 2025, two-thirds of all U.S. jobs will require education beyond high school.This prediction underscores the need for upskilling in an AI-driven economy. As AI tools become integral to various roles, individuals and organizations must prioritize education and training to remain competitive. Gates’ vision aligns with the broader trend of integrating AI into workplaces, highlighting the importance of lifelong learning in an evolving job market.Werner Vogels, Amazon’s Chief Technology Officer, emphasizes the cultural shifts driven by technology. He predicts a "quiet revolution" in 2025, where workers, particularly Millennials and Gen Zers, prioritize purpose over financial success.In a December blog post, Vogels noted that people are increasingly seeking roles that contribute positively to society. “Harnessing technology for good has become both an ethical imperative and a profitable endeavor,” Vogels stated.He also highlighted the growing awareness of the mental health implications of technology, particularly among younger generations. Vogels predicts that 2025 will see a rise in alternative technologies, such as simplified “dumb phones,” as consumers seek to redefine their relationship with digital tools.Clement Delangue, CEO of AI startup Hugging Face, anticipates a more confrontational approach to AI in 2025. He predicts the first major public protest against AI technologies, driven by concerns about privacy, job displacement, and ethical considerations.Delangue’s perspective underscores the need for transparency and ethical frameworks in deploying AI. As AI continues to integrate into daily life, companies must address public apprehensions and ensure responsible development.Don McGuire, CFO of management services company ADP, highlights the practical applications of AI in streamlining business processes. ADP leverages GenAI to assist sales representatives, prepare for investor events, and enhance operational efficiency.McGuire sees 2025 as a year of increased AI adoption in business, stating, “Things that people used to sit beside you and have a headset, now you can do those things with GenAI tools.” His outlook reflects the broader trend of AI transforming traditional workflows, emphasizing its role in improving productivity and decision-making.Delangue also foresees a surge in consumer interest in personal AI robots. He predicts that companies like Tesla will lead the charge, with at least 100,000 personal AI robots expected to be pre-ordered in 2025. These robots, equipped with advanced AI capabilities, could redefine household management and personal assistance, bridging the gap between science fiction and reality.Michael Perica, CFO of Rimini Street, highlights the economic challenges businesses may face in 2025 due to trade policies and tariffs. He points to the impact of Donald Trump’s second presidential term, where promised tariffs on imported goods could lead to higher consumer prices and supply chain disruptions.Perica suggests that businesses will increasingly rely on AI to offset these challenges, using technology to streamline operations and prioritize critical initiatives. His analysis underscores the interconnectedness of economic policies and technological adoption, as companies navigate a rapidly changing landscape.

Article Title: US bans China's most-valuable internet company; ‘clearly a mistake’ says the Chinese giant
Article Text:
What is Pentagon’s Chinese military company list

What it means for Tencent



What Tencent has to say

Tencent, the Chinese social media and gaming giant, has been labeled as a ‘ Chinese military company ’ by the Pentagon on Monday, January 6 marking another escalation in the ongoing feud between the United States and China. Other than Tencent Holdings Limited , other Chinese firms, including battery maker CATL, drone manufacturer Autel Robotics, and shipping giant COSCO were also added to the list. As posted in the Federal Register, the newly expanded list now includes 134 companies.The Pentagon's Chinese military company list is a catalog of companies identified by the US Department of Defense as entities that support or are linked to the Chinese military while also engaging in commercial operations. The list is part of an effort by the US government to address concerns about China's military-civil fusion strategy, where private companies are allegedly leveraged to advance the country's military and technological capabilities.The Pentagon updates its list of "Chinese military companies" annually, identifying entities it claims combine commercial and military technologies.Companies on this list face warnings that US businesses working with them could risk losing future Pentagon contracts. The designation of Tencent and other firms highlights the deepening rift between the two superpowers, with economic, technological, and military competition driving the increasingly aggressive policies on both sides.The listing sent Tencent's US-listed shares tumbling nearly 10%.The decision also affects other Chinese giants. CATL, which licenses battery technology to Ford Motor for a $3.5 billion electric vehicle factory in Michigan, was among the newly listed firms.In its response, Tencent stated that the inclusion was "clearly a mistake," asserting that the company is "not a military company or supplier" and emphasizing that the designation would have "no impact on our business."The company further added that it intends to "work with the Department of Defense to address any misunderstanding."
Article Summary: The Pentagon's Chinese military company list is a catalog of companies identified by the US Department of Defense as entities that support or are linked to the Chinese military. Article Summary: HCLTech has reportedly rolled out salary hikes to junior employees. Article Title: After phones and laptops, Google is bringing Gemini AI to this everyday device
Article Text:
What Gemini on Google TV means for users

Google TVs to get upgraded hardware

At CES 2025 , Google has announced that it is bringing Gemini AI-powered features to Google TVs this year. The company unveiled a suite of new AI-powered features for Google TV , designed to make interacting with your television more intuitive and helpful.“At this year's CES, we shared a preview of new AI capabilities for Google TV that use our Gemini models to make interacting with your TV more intuitive and helpful. You and your family will be able to gather together and have a natural conversation with your TV,” the company said.Leveraging the power of Google's Gemini models, these features aim to transform select Google TV models into a conversational and interactive hub for entertainment, information, and smart home control.“This will make searching through your media easier than ever, and you will be able to ask questions about travel, health, space, history and more, with videos in the results for added context,” Google added.Moreover, the Gemini model on Google TV will also enable users to create personalised artwork with their family, control their smart home devices while the TV is in ambient mode, and even get a summary of the day’s news.These new features are expected to roll out later this year on select Google TV devices, including from Sony, Hisense and TCL. Notably, Google rolled out Gemini-powered features to the Google TV Streamer.As per a report by Android Police, Google TV is also getting a hardware upgrade such as far-field microphones for hands-free voice control. Google TVs may ditch the need for a remote control with the integration of far-field microphones. This allows users to interact with Google Assistant naturally, just like with a Google Home speaker.These Google TVs will also get proximity sensors that will detect when users approach the TV, triggering an on-screen hub with personalised widgets displaying information like weather, news, and commute updates.
Article Summary: Google has announced that it is bringing Gemini AI-powered features to Google TVs this year. These features aim to transform select Google TV models into a conversational and interactive hub for entertainment, information, and smart home control. Google TVs will also get proximity sensors that will detect when users approach the TV, triggering an on-screen hub.

Article Title: Tata Consulting Engineers buys 75-year-old US company; eight engineering centres and other key details of the deal
Article Text:
Representative image

TCE is a 100% subsidiary of Tata Sons.

Founded in 1950, Houston-based CDI has over 600 employees.

The acquisition of the 75-year-old CDI, which has a client base including several Fortune 500 companies, gives TCE eight US-based engineering centers and complements company's existing strengths.

What TCE said on the acquisition of CDI

Tata Consulting Engineers (TCE) has purchased US-based CDI Engineering Solutions , formerly Comprehensive Designers Inc (CDI). Part of the Tata Group , Tata Consulting Engineers is a design, engineering, and project management consultancy company. Tata Consulting Engineers or TCE has acquired Comprehensive Designers Inc with the aim to enter the North American market .The financial terms of the deal have not been disclosed.The combined organization aims to provide integrated solutions addressing critical global challenges, including clean energy transition, decarbonization, and resilient infrastructure.TCE’s global delivery platform will now include CDI’s eight engineering centres in the US.TCE stated that the acquisition is a "deliberate step" to expand its global reach and expertise. “The acquisition of CDI marks a deliberate step towards expanding TCE’s global footprint and scaling its expertise… With its expertise and a client base that includes several Fortune 500 companies, CDI’s capabilities complement TCE’s strengths in engineering design and project management,” TCE said in a statement.TCE Managing Director and CEO Amit Sharma said that the combined entity will be a "competitive entity capable of delivering exceptional value to clients" and addressing global priorities like energy transition and sustainable infrastructure. CDI President Steve Karlovic highlighted the shared commitment to engineering excellence and sustainability, emphasizing the growth opportunities for employees.TCE, originally founded in 1962 as Tata Ebasco (a joint venture between Tata Group and US-based Ebasco Services Inc.), became a wholly owned subsidiary of Tata Sons in 1968. In fiscal year 2024, TCE's consolidated revenue was Rs 1,406 crore (approximately $170 million USD), with India accounting for roughly 60% and domestic government clients contributing about 35%, according to ICRA. The company employs over 6,000 people.
Article Summary: Tata Consulting Engineers (TCE) has purchased US-based CDI Engineering Solutions, formerly Comprehensive Designers Inc (CDI) TCE stated that the acquisition is a "deliberate step" to expand its global reach and expertise. The combined organization aims to provide integrated solutions addressing critical global challenges, including clean energy transition and decarbonization.

Article Title: CES 2025: This smart mirror can show multiple health data by reading faces
Article Text:
Image credit: Withings

Withings Omnia smart mirror: How is it different



French consumer electronics company Withings has unveiled a concept mirror named Omnia at CES 2025 . This smart mirror combines health tracking , AI assistance , and telehealth capabilities . The device features a base that measures weight, heart health, and metabolic health, and can integrate data from other health trackers. The mirror also has an AI voice assistant that provides real-time feedback and guidance, while also potentially facilitating virtual consultations with doctors. Omnia can even send health data to doctors for review, offering a comprehensive and futuristic approach to health management.Omnia is not yet a commercially available product; Withings has stated that it is "currently in development," with no clear timeline or pricing details. Given Withings' history of CES announcements, it could be a long wait before Omnia reaches consumers if it ever does.One of the biggest highlights of the Omnia concept mirror is how it combines several existing health tech trends into one cohesive package. It's important to note that connected smart mirrors , which can display information, make video calls, and play sound, aren't new—these features were already present in Lululemon's Mirror and its imitators.Similarly, smart scales capable of measuring heart rate, taking EKGs, and analyzing body composition have also been available for years. Additionally, AI chatbots integrated into health tech emerged as a growing trend in 2024, with major brands like Oura, Whoop, and Fitbit exploring these technologies.Withings plans to offer demos at CES 2025, which may provide insight into whether Omnia is a legitimate product or just another example of CES health tech hype. Regardless of whether it becomes a tangible product, Omnia reflects the direction in which health tech is headed.Apart from this, Withings offers smartwatches, smart scales, connected blood pressure cuffs, smart thermometers, and even a noninvasive sleep tracker that fits under a mattress. The company has previously debuted products like an at-home urinalysis device for toilets and scales that analyze nerve health through the feet. It has also incorporated telemedicine features , such as cardiologist-reviewed EKG results in its FDA-cleared ScanWatch.
Article Summary: French consumer electronics company Withings has unveiled a concept mirror named Omnia at CES 2025. This smart mirror combines health tracking, AI assistance, and telehealth capabilities. The mirror also has an AI voice assistant that provides real-time feedback and guidance, while also potentially facilitating virtual consultations with doctors.

Article Title: OpenAI CEO Sam Altman on superintelligence: We’re pretty confident that...
Article Text: ChatGPT maker OpenAI is now looking to develop superintelligence — AI systems with cognitive abilities far surpassing human capabilities -- across every domain, from scientific creativity to social skills, CEO Sam Altman said in a recent blogpost.With superintelligent tools, scientific discovery and innovation could accelerate “well beyond what we are capable of doing on our own,” he said In a previous blog, Altman had even suggested that superintelligence might emerge in a “few thousand days.”Altman wrote that superintelligence might sound like science fiction. “We’re pretty confident that in the next few years, everyone will see what we see, and that the need to act with great care, while still maximising broad benefit and empowerment, is so important. Given the possibilities of our work, OpenAI cannot be a normal company.”Previously, OpenAI had also said strong public oversight is needed when it comes to governing superintelligence, , asserting that the global community should have a democratic role in determining the bounds and defaults for AI systems. The company proposed an international authority to ensure safety, regulate advanced AI and manage risks, while avoiding over-regulation of less advanced systems.Altman also looked back on the journey of ChatGPT, which was initially dubbed “Chat With GPT-3.5.” Launched over two years ago on November 30, 2022, ChatGPT sparked a “growth curve like nothing we have ever seen,” he added.Altman shared how the project has now “transitioned into the next paradigm of models that can do complex reasoning,” marking the ongoing shift toward Artificial General Intelligence (AGI).At a New York Times’s DealBook Summit last year, he speculated that AGI could potentially emerge within this year . He reaffirmed the same in the blog, saying “we may see the first AI agents “join the workforce” and materially change the output of companies.”He also addressed various other topics, including the issue of being removed from OpenAI’s board after they "lost confidence in his leadership abilities." He described the event as a “big failure of governance by well-meaning people,” acknowledging his own role in the situation.
Article Summary: ChatGPT maker OpenAI is now looking to develop superintelligence. CEO Sam Altman wrote that superintelligence might sound like science fiction. He also addressed the issue of being removed from OpenAI’s board after they "lost confidence in his leadership abilities"

Article Title: OpenAI CEO Sam Altman breaks silence a year after his failed firing: 'They f*cked me and the company'
Article Text:
The firing that led to series of resignations

OpenAI CEO Sam Altman revealed inheriting a "complete mess" and a company "on fire" after his dramatic return as chief executive, he shared in a Bloomberg interview published on Sunday.Altman, who was abruptly fired and then rehired within five days last November, revealed that the situation deteriorated daily after his return, citing mounting government investigations and what he characterized as former board members leaking "fake news" to the press."All those people that I feel like really fucked me and fucked the company were gone, and now I had to clean up their mess," Altman told Bloomberg, referring to the aftermath of the leadership crisis that saw most of the original board members depart.The turmoil triggered a series of high-profile departures throughout 2024, including co-founder Ilya Sutskever, who had initially voted for Altman's removal, and superalignment team co-lead Jan Leike. Both joined competitor Anthropic, along with John Schulman, another OpenAI co-founder who departed in August. Chief Technology Officer Mira Murati also left the company in September.The November 2023 crisis began when the board claimed Altman "was not consistently candid in his communications," though specific details were never disclosed. The decision sparked an employee revolt, with nearly all staff threatening to quit unless Altman was reinstated.Only one board member from the original group that voted for Altman's removal, Quora CEO Adam D'Angelo, remains at OpenAI. The company, which began as a nonprofit in 2015, is now reportedly in discussions with California's attorney general's office about transitioning to a for-profit structure.
Article Summary: OpenAI CEO Sam Altman says he inherited a "complete mess" and a company "on fire" after his dramatic return as chief executive. Altman was abruptly fired and then rehired within five days last November. The turmoil triggered a series of high-profile departures, including co-founder Ilya Sutskever.

Article Title: How Google may have solved one of the biggest AI 'problems’
Article Text:
What is “peak data” and how it is a problem for AI industry

What is inference-time compute and how it works

The performance of an AI model relies on one important thing: data. Recently, OpenAI cofounder Ilya Sutskever declared that the AI industry has reached “peak data”, suggesting that all useful data present on the internet has been exhausted for training AI models. However, Google seems to have found a solution to this problem.“Peak data” is a term used to describe the amount of available useful data to train an AI model. The AI industry is facing a " peak data " challenge wherein all useful data has already been used for training AI models.Since all the high-quality data readily available on the internet has already been used to train existing AI models, newer models might not show significant improvements over their predecessors because they're not learning from substantially new or better information.However, Google DeepMind researchers are optimistic, pointing to a promising solution: inference-time compute , as per a report by Business Insider.This technique allows AI models to tackle complex tasks by breaking them down into smaller, manageable prompts. Each step involves a new inference request, creating a chain of reasoning where the model only progresses after solving each part correctly.This process leads to higher-quality outputs, especially in tasks with clear answers, like math problems. The breakthrough lies in using these improved outputs as fresh training data.Google DeepMind researchers proposed this method in August, suggesting an “iterative self-improvement loop” where enhanced outputs are fed back into the model for further training. This approach could bypass the “peak data” problem and fuel continued AI development.Reportedly, early results are promising, with models like OpenAI's o1 and DeepSeek V3 demonstrating significant improvements. Microsoft CEO Satya Nadella expressed confidence in inference-time compute, calling it “another scaling law” for enhancing AI capabilities.“So you have pre-training, and then you have effectively this test-time sampling that then creates the tokens that can go back into pre-training, creating even more powerful models that then are running on your inference,” he said."That's I think a fantastic way to increase model capability," Nadella added.
Article Summary: The AI industry is facing a " peak data " challenge wherein all useful data has already been used for training AI models. Google DeepMind researchers are optimistic, pointing to a promising solution: inference-time compute. This technique allows AI models to tackle complex tasks by breaking them down into smaller, manageable prompts.
